itemDescription: British politician who sat in the House of Commons in 1614

wikipedia_page.main:
William Jones (died July 1640) was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons  in 1614. Jones was the son of John Jones of Treowen. In 1614, Jones was elected Member of Parliament for Monmouthshire. He was High Sheriff of Monmouthshire in 1615. 
He was responsible for rebuilding the family house at Treowen where he lived in 1628.Jones married Jane Gwillim (or Gwilym), daughter of Moore Gwillim of Monmouth.

response: | Walter Montagu  William Jones
| William Jones

The house was built in about 1623–27 for William Jones, on the site of a 15th-century building. Tre-Owen at British Listed Buildings.  Accessed 2 February 2012  Jones was briefly Member of Parliament for Monmouthshire in 1614, and was High Sheriff of Monmouthshire in 1615.  He later inherited a fortune from his uncle, a trader in London. History, at Treowen website .  Accessed 2 February 2012
